title: House Panel to Probe Chao Over Possible Conflicts of Interest
summary: The House Oversight and Reform Committee has requested documents as it looks into whether Chao used her position to benefit her family. WASHINGTON-The House Oversight and Reform Committee is launching an ethics inquiry into whether Elaine Chao is using her role as head of the Transportation Department to benefit her family.

title: Trump Moves Ahead With U.S.-Japan Trade Pact That Eases Some Tariffs
summary: American agricultural exporters have been disadvantaged ever since Trump pulled out of the Trans-Pacific Partnership at the beginning of his presidency. WASHINGTON-President Trump notified Congress on Monday that the U.S. and Japan were prepared to enter a limited agreement that would lower some tariffs and set terms of digital trade.

title: 'Permanent Record' Review: A Hero in His Own Mind
summary: The leaker of hundreds of thousands of computer files-revealing military and intelligence secrets-tells his story.. Edward Snowden, the former U.S. intelligence officer and contractor who in 2013 leaked a trove of classified documents to select journalists for allegedly principled reasons and then fled the country, has done what anybody in his position would be expected to do: He has written a self-exculpating memoir.

title: The Assault on the Supreme Court
summary: The revival of smears against Kavanaugh is part of a campaign.. Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh will apparently receive continuing education in the politics of personal destruction, and this weekend came another round of rumor-mill accusations over his conduct in college. It's important to understand that this assault on the Justice is part of the left's larger campaign against the legitimacy of the current Supreme Court and an independent judiciary.

title: Paul Ingrassia
summary: A longtime Journal editor and chronicler of the auto industry.. The editor across the desk could not have been clearer. Either stop making factual errors or you'll have to find another line of work. That was the message nearly 40 years ago to the editor of these columns from Paul Ingrassia, who died Monday of cancer at age 69 after one of the great careers at the Journal and indeed in American journalism.

title: No Peace in Our Time in Colombia
summary: Key FARC drug smugglers renew the guerrilla war.. Fewer than three years after Colombia's oldest guerrilla group signed a peace agreement with the government, the terror leaders have said never mind. In a 32-minute video broadcast last month, Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) commander Iván Márquez called for a "new phase of the armed struggle." By his side were FARC commanders Jesús Santrich and Hernán Dario Velásquez-better known as the bloodthirsty El Paisa-and gun-toting grunts.

title: Broadway Sees Box Office Magic in Comedians, Rock Stars, Illusionists
summary: 'Derren Brown: Secret' and 'Freestyle Love Supreme' are among latest nontheatrical productions to grace Great White Way. The next big thing on Broadway may not be a musical or play.

title: Pin the Asterisk on Kavanaugh
summary: Christine Blasey Ford was motivated by politics, her lawyer asserted in April.. It's just shy of a year since Brett Kavanaugh took his seat on the Supreme Court. On cue, the New York Times on Sunday published a "previously unreported story" claiming that as a Yale undergraduate at a "drunken dorm party," Mr. Kavanaugh had his pants down while friends pushed his genitals "into the hands of a female student." The accusation is similar to Deborah Ramirez's assertion last year in the New Yorker about another drunken Yale party.

title: China and Trump Are Making Japan Nervous
summary: Tokyo is committed to the Pacific alliance. Can Washington get its act together?. Tokyo

title: Israel's Election Is Full of Wild Cards
summary: The result could help bridge the religious-secular divide. Or it could end the Netanyahu era.. Israel's repeat election Tuesday may reinforce the dominance of the right-and begin to bridge the divide between religious and secular Jews that has plagued Israel since the state was established. But polls are tight. If the vote swings left, it will likely spell the end of the Benjamin Netanyahu era.

title: Hell Without a Handbasket
summary: Dear women under 30: Where have your purses gone?. It almost broke my heart. I was sitting in church behind a lovely, painstakingly put-together young mother. The chair next to her was piled with the following: an iPhone, sunglasses, lip balm and an enormous ring of keys that would be the envy of innkeepers and school custodians the world over. That's four things-along with two preschool-age children-to keep track of, to scoop up at the service's end, to count once back in the car.

title: The Fed's Mandate Is Up to Congress and the President
summary: Lawmakers in the past have broadened the central bank's goals, directing it to boost U.S. competitiveness.. The role of the Federal Reserve as an instrument of public economic power could use some clarification. The central bank's status as an independent agency derives from an act of Congress in 1913, and is reinforced by oft-invoked references to its statutory "dual mandate": to achieve stable prices and full employment.

title: What Ever Happened to 'We the People'?
summary: There's more to the U.S. Constitution than its amendments. Give the preamble some respect.. Sometimes you know something so well that you stop seeking out what it can teach you. This can happen with anything from a beloved novel to the Bible. In our divisive political times, one well-worn text that bears re-examining is the preamble of the Constitution. Many Americans memorized its words in school-or by watching "Schoolhouse Rock!"-but few examined its meaning closely.

title: Spain Frees Ex-Venezuela Spy Chief Wanted by U.S. on Drug Charges
summary: Hugo Carvajal, who turned against the Maduro regime early this year, won't be extradited to U.S.. Spain's National Court ordered Venezuela's former top spy released from jail Monday, rejecting a U.S. extradition request seeking the former official on drug-trafficking charges.

title: New York City Department of Education Botched Bus-Tracking System, Report Says
summary: City's Special Commissioner of Investigation says $9 million GPS program was mismanaged. A city watchdog agency said Monday the New York City Department of Education bungled running a system to track school buses for disabled children, leaving the city unable to recoup millions of dollars in federal reimbursements.

title: SeaWorld Entertainment CEO Resigns After Seven Months
summary: Finance chief Marc Swanson will act as interim CEO following Gustavo Antorcha's departure. SeaWorld Entertainment Inc. said Monday that Chief Executive Gustavo Antorcha is leaving the company, seven months after taking the helm.

title: OPEC, Russia to Hold Off Pumping More Oil After Attacks in Saudi Arabia
summary: Saudi Arabia will tap into stocks, officials say, as they worry fellow OPEC members might overproduce. OPEC and Russia are so far holding off pumping more oil to fill potential gaps in global supplies after an attack in Saudi Arabia over the weekend led to a major crude disruption, officials said.

title: UAW Strike Could Cost GM $100 Million a Day
summary: Walkout comes at delicate time for both auto maker and union. General Motors Co. stands to lose as much as $100 million a day if the nationwide strike of auto workers continues.

title: Former Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi to Unveil New Party
summary: Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte will now have to manage three parties instead of two in governing coalition. ROME-Italy's new government suffered its first setback, as the country's center-left party split in two, complicating life for an already unwieldy governing coalition.

title: Connecticut Governor Ned Lamont Plans to End Religious Exemption For Vaccinations
summary: The state would introduce legislation requiring minors to be vaccinated, with few exceptions. Connecticut Gov. Ned Lamont said on Monday that the state should join a handful of others that require minors to receive vaccinations for preventable diseases, eliminating most exceptions to vaccination.

title: Purdue Looks to Extend Bankruptcy Shield to Sackler Family
summary: OxyContin maker's lawyers will ask judge to block action from states not agreeing to settlement. OxyContin maker Purdue Pharma LP's bankruptcy filing sets up a showdown with law-enforcement officials seeking to rein in the industry they blame for causing the national opioid epidemic.

title: Islamic State Releases Purported Audio Message From Leader
summary: Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi calls on followers to intensify their efforts after losing control of territory. BEIRUT-Islamic State leader Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi ordered his followers to redouble their efforts to further the extremist group's cause, in an audio message apparently aimed at raising morale after it lost control over its self-proclaimed caliphate in parts of Syria and Iraq earlier this year.

title: Paul Ingrassia, Prizewinning Automotive Journalist and Author, Dies at 69
summary: Writer held senior posts at The Wall Street Journal, Dow Jones Newswires and Thomson Reuters. Paul Ingrassia, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist for The Wall Street Journal who was one of the leading chroniclers of the auto industry for more than three decades, died Monday in Naples, Fla., where he had been under treatment for pancreatic cancer. He was 69 years old.

title: Aspect Ventures' Partners Break Up Firm
summary: Five years after founding the venture-capital firm, Theresia Gouw and Jennifer Fonstad are parting ways to launch new firms. The founders of Aspect Ventures, a prominent female-led venture-capital firm, are parting ways to launch separate firms.

title: Frackers to Stand Pat, Reap Profits After Attacks on Saudi Oil
summary: Large shale producers aim to show financial discipline after losing investor support. Major U.S. shale companies aren't planning to fill the void in global crude supplies left by an attack on the heart of Saudi Arabia's top oil facilities.

title: Prudential Pays $32.6 Million to Settle Probe of Mutual-Fund Business
summary: SEC claimed 2006 reorganization led to conflict of interest. WASHINGTON- Prudential Financial Inc. agreed to pay $32.6 million to settle claims that it didn't disclose how a reorganization of its mutual-fund business would cost the funds millions in lost interest income.

title: GM Workers Head to Picket Lines to Press Demands
summary: Union members demonstrate for better new-hire pay, fewer temp workers, preservation of health care plans. General Motors Co. 's factory workers took to the picket lines Monday, hoisting signs reading "UAW on Strike" and blocking traffic into plants, in an effort to secure better pay, more job security and other benefits ahead of an expected U.S. car market slowdown.

title: New York Prosecutors Subpoena Trump Tax Returns
summary: Move is part of probe examining whether payment to Stormy Daniels violated state business-records law. State prosecutors in Manhattan have subpoenaed eight years of President Trump's tax returns from his longtime accounting firm, according to a person familiar with the matter.

title: 'Common Practice' by Ethan Iverson Review: Swinging Standards With a Contemporary Twist
summary: On an album recorded at the Village Vanguard, the pianist leads a quartet in revealing the unexpected in familiar songs..

title: Weill Cornell Medicine Joins Other Schools in Cutting Student Debt
summary: Expanded $160 million scholarship program aims to eliminate debt for those demonstrating financial need. New York City's Weill Cornell Medicine said Monday that it would increase its scholarship offerings to eliminate education debt for students demonstrating financial need, an expansion that follows other similar debt-relief efforts at medical schools in the city.

title: MTA Wants to Spend $55 Billion to Improve Your Commute
summary: Plan, which still needs to be approved, includes introduction of new elevators at 70 subway stations and new signaling technology. The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to spend an unprecedented $55 billion over the next five years to modernize its two commuter rail lines, its bridges and tunnels, and New York City's subway and bus systems.

title: Democrats and China
summary: The tariffs may be here for a while.. A new Morning Consult poll conducted after last Thursday's Democratic presidential debate finds that former Vice President Joe Biden remains the favorite. Among Democratic primary voters nationwide, 32% support Mr. Biden, while 20% back Sen. Bernie Sanders and 18% favor Sen. Elizabeth Warren. What should concern the Chinese dictatorship is that while they all criticize the manner in which Donald Trump is confronting Beijing, they are all endorsing a hard line on China trade.

title: 'William Bailey: Looking Through Time' Review: Realism Reimagined
summary: While abstraction dominated the art world, the painter continued to make representational works drawn from his imagination that moved beyond the everyday or mundane..

summary: Rahul Ghai joins the elevator maker from defense company L3 Harris Technologies. Otis Elevator Co. hired a new finance chief as it gets ready to separate from industrial conglomerate United Technologies Corp.

title: Opioid Relief Rally Is Likely to Stall
summary: Recent jump in opioid stocks has come despite many unanswered questions about future liability. Momentum in settlement talks to resolve opioid litigation has spurred a stock-market rally, but the danger for investors is far from over.

summary: Haven assets like gold and the Japanese yen gain. The Dow Jones Industrial Average snapped an eight-session winning streak and haven assets rallied after a weekend attack on Saudi Arabian oil facilities sent crude prices surging.

title: U.S. Energy Shares Soar After Attacks on Saudi Oil Facilities
summary: Crude producers Whiting, Centennial and California Resources among biggest gainers. Shares of U.S. energy producers surged after weekend attacks on Saudi oil production facilities knocked out 6% of global oil output, giving a boost to stocks that have beaten down by low commodity prices and investors wary of glutted commodity markets.

title: New Relic Lowers Outlook, Shakes Up Executive Ranks
summary: Technology chief and chief revenue officer depart. New Relic Inc. cut its yearly revenue outlook on Monday and said two top executives had departed.

summary: American Airlines, United Airlines among hardest hit. Shares of airlines and truckers slipped Monday after crude prices soared, the latest fallout from weekend attacks on Saudi Arabian oil facilities.

title: Podcasters Seek 'Hey, Can You Believe This Happened to Me?' Stories
summary: A serial killer's daughter is among individuals adding a thrilling personal perspective to 'The Clearing' and other hit podcasts. On episode 2 of "The Clearing," a podcast about serial killer Edward Wayne Edwards, journalist and author Josh Dean describes how he obsessively sought a cache of evidence that police had gathered nine years earlier from Edwards's trailer in Louisville, Ky. The boxes were rumored to have been transferred to a small sheriff's office in Geauga County, Ohio, but Mr. Dean was told he would need a court order if he ever hoped to see them. His collaborator on the project, a 50-year-old mother of three named April Balascio, thought she might have better luck.

title: Netflix Reaches Streaming Deal for 'Seinfeld'
summary: The streaming giant adds the hit NBC sitcom from the 1990s as 'Friends' and 'The Office' are set to move to other services. Netflix Inc. is losing streaming rights to "Friends" but -yada yada yada-now it is getting rights to "Seinfeld."

title: SEC Charges Third Cognizant Executive With Foreign Bribery
summary: Technology company's former chief operating officer reaches settlement with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Cognizant Technology Solutions Corp.'s former chief operating officer has agreed to pay a $50,000 fine to settle civil charges that he helped authorize and conceal a bribe paid to an Indian official.

title: Justice Department Charges Three Metals Contract Traders
summary: One former and two current JPMorgan Chase traders indicted. Two traders and one former executive at JPMorgan Chase & Co. were indicted and charged with manipulating prices for precious-metals futures contracts over an eight-year period.

title: Jonathan Safran Foer on the Shame That Might Save the World
summary: In 'We Are the Weather,' the writer interrogates himself and his habits in order to help everyone face the planetary crisis. Jonathan Safran Foer's latest book, We Are the Weather: Saving the Planet Begins at Breakfast, is an earnest call to action in the face of climate change, but it's not a polemic. Instead, it's a personal exploration. The writer, who became a star while still in his 20s with his first novel, Everything Is Illuminated, finds himself a father of two in his 40s who is incapable of mustering the necessary emotion to change his life in light of the damning science of the planetary crisis. Throughout the formally diverse book-one section consists of an interior debate, written as dialogue; another section is composed entirely of bullet-pointed facts about the crisis-Foer agonizes over why he won't take action. Specifically, he struggles to abstain from eating animal products for breakfast and lunch, which he believes would significantly reduce one's carbon footprint.

title: Mona Sinha on How Women Can Use Their Wealth to Do Good
summary: Women who give will realize how they can change the world today and for generations to come, she says. Some women aren't comfortable with the word "philanthropist," says Mona Sinha, board member of Women Moving Millions, a global group of women making gifts of $1 million or more for the advancement of women and girls.

title: Frontier to Make Debt Payments, Soothing Bankruptcy Fears
summary: Wireless company defies market speculation of a near-term bankruptcy. Frontier Communications Corp. on Monday was set to make roughly $320 million of debt payments, at least temporarily easing fears of a near-term bankruptcy filing for the wireline telecom company.

title: Baker Hughes Sheds an Owner and Six Syllables
summary: Shareholders didn't cheer when GE dumped shares of Baker Hughes, but analysts probably did. If you look at most storied American companies, numerous corporate combinations helped them get where they are today. Most had the good sense to pare down their names as their family trees became ever more complicated, but someone forgot to tell General Electric .

title: Former Oil CEO Aims to Change How the U.S. Exports Natural Gas
summary: Forrest Hoglund challenges LNG technology with SeaOne Holdings and looks for toehold in Latin America. An oil-industry stalwart is hoping to undercut the way most U.S. natural gas is shipped abroad, using a newly patented method he says is cheaper because it requires less upfront investment than the dominant technology, liquefied natural gas or LNG.

title: Pittsburgh Panic: Steelers' Ben Roethlisberger Is Out for the Season
summary: An 0-2 record doesn't mean the end for an NFL franchise. Or does it?. If you are a Pittsburgh Steelers fan, this is a bleak, soul-challenging moment. I don't blame you if you're currently wandering around in the woods, staring up at the trees, listening to the melancholy whistle of the September wind, and wondering what's the point of watching football anymore.

title: In Texas, a Surprise Fight for Control of the State House
summary: Republicans fear a scandal involving state House speaker could give Democrats majority for first time in almost two decades. AUSTIN-A scandal at the heart of the Texas House of Representatives has thrown Republicans in the state into turmoil and led to jitters over whether it could be the straw that breaks the party's longstanding hold on power here.

title: Canadian Official Charged With Leaks Had Access to Foreign Intelligence
summary: RCMP's director general of national-intelligence coordination accused of violating state-secrets law. OTTAWA-A senior Canadian intelligence official facing five charges for violating the country's state-secrets law had access to intelligence collected domestically and by Canada's foreign allies, such as the U.S. and U.K., Canadian police said Monday.

title: EU Braces for U.S. Tariffs Over Airbus Dispute
summary: Trade commissioner says Washington is unwilling to strike settlement over Airbus, Boeing subsidy cases; EU ready to impose retaliatory levies. BRUSSELS-The U.S. is poised to impose new tariffs on European Union exports over the bloc's subsidies to Airbus SE , the EU's trade chief said Monday, citing the Trump administration's unwillingness to settle a long-running commercial dispute over aircraft manufacturers.

title: Strikes in Saudi Arabia Chill Diplomacy-Perhaps by Design
summary: Timing of attacks is deeply suspicious, with plenty of actors who don't want an outbreak of diplomacy. Diplomacy is hard. Stopping diplomacy, by contrast, is relatively easy. Hard-liners across the Middle East know this, and long have acted accordingly.

title: In Comeback, Macron Steers Straight for Fresh Clash With Streets
summary: With his popularity on the rise, French president tackles contentious issues, including overhauling the country's sacred pension system. The pro-business presidency of Emmanuel Macron, buried beneath months of yellow-vest protests, has risen from the dead.

title: The Fed's Tail-Chasing Problem
summary: The Federal Reserve's current policy reasoning could push rates sharply lower in response to remote risks. The U.S. economy is probably going to be fine, but the Federal Reserve looks likely to lower rates this week anyway.

title: Sen. Warren's Plan Will Punish the Prudent
summary: Individuals who deferred spending for the security of their later years, did so with the promise and guidance of various laws passed by Congress such as the Roth IRA.. Phil Gramm and Mike Solon start "Warren's Assault on Retiree Wealth" (op-ed, Sept. 11) by telling the reader that the households of ages 65 to 74 have an average of $1,066,000 in net worth. This may be technically true but it has little significance in a political or public-policy context.

title: Public Interest, Yes, but Is Reporter's Privilege Right?
summary: How can journalists claim a constitutional right the rest of us don't have?. David B. Rivkin and Lee A. Casey are spot on in their analysis of journalists' claim to special status against the "coordinated communications" prohibition of federal election law ("End the Media's Campaign Privilege," op-ed, Sept. 4). A similar analysis applies to claims for a "reporter's privilege" protecting against divulging sources (even for information obtained illegally). Again, how can journalists claim a constitutional right the rest of us don't have?

title: World Auto Industry Is Becoming Socialized
summary: Auto makers are increasingly being mandated to direct capital investment into unprofitable products, then rely on government subsides to reduce the losses and taxpayer-funded credits to customers to drive up demand.. In the same issue as your editorial "Progressive Antitrust Paradox" (Sept 12) about four auto makers's corporate collusion to build more electric cars to meet California's more stringent standards, your Technology section has "European Auto Makers Bet on Electric" about the challenges auto makers are facing because more and more of their product planning is being based on government mandates rather than the market demand they should serve.

title: ETF's Are an Incomplete Answer for Diversification
summary: While it may be important to focus on each individual ETF's diversification, investors should seek diversification for their entire portfolio.. While it may be important to focus on each individual ETF's diversification, investors should seek diversification for their entire portfolio ("Your 'Diversified' ETF Might Now Be Anything But," Journal Report, Sept. 9). Investors will reduce their market risk and achieve broad diversification by investing in more than just growth funds or a U.S.-based index no matter how diversified those individual funds may be. Since small companies have historically outperformed large, and value companies have historically outperformed growth, investors won't only achieve broad diversification but increase their expected total return by owning the entire global market and then tilting more of their investible funds to the small and value asset classes, both in the U.S. and abroad. The academic evidence is very clear on this as demonstrated over the years by Eugene Fama, Kenneth French and many others.

title: It's Not That Hard to Tell Marijuana From Hemp
summary: We use a tool called Purpl PRO to test potency. It costs about $1,500 and we find it to be accurate within acceptable tolerances.. Regarding South Dakota Gov. Kristi Noem's "Why I Won't Support Legalizing Hemp" (op-ed, Sept. 10): I believe Gov. Noem needs to enhance her staff's research capability. We are cannabis growers in Oregon and use a tool called Purpl PRO, sold by Purpl Scientific. I'm sure there are other such tools available. It costs about $1,500, and we find it to be accurate within acceptable tolerances. After we test our cannabis for THC potency, independent labs test the product before it is put on the shelf. The device is hand-held, gives results within minutes and can be used in the field. Problem solved.

title: No Brexit Breakthrough as U.K. Prime Minister Meets With Top EU Official
summary: EU's Juncker says the bloc is awaiting concrete proposals for how to avoid a 'backstop,' damping hopes of a swift agreement. summary: Money is a focus as the U.S. women's national team alleges unfair pay. Advertisers shelled out almost $100 million on U.S. TV commercials in and around the 2019 FIFA Women's World Cup, exceeding expectations.

summary: The yuan is languishing in currency-trading rankings, highlighting international skepticism about Beijing's tight control over the renminbi. SHANGHAI-China's progress in boosting international use of its currency is stalling.

summary: Resume Subscription. Amazon.com Inc. has adjusted its product-search system to more prominently feature listings that are more profitable for the company, said people who worked on the project-a move, contested internally, that could favor Amazon's own brands.

summary: Her latest tour, which opens Tuesday, is planned around theaters rather than arenas, and fans will be paying more-especially at the high end. When Madonna kicks off her new tour Tuesday, she'll also be debuting a new ticket-pricing strategy: Smaller shows at higher prices.

summary: Lou Ferrigno, who played the fictional superhero on television, is selling his Santa Monica property with what he calls 'the best home gym in the country'. title: Football Coaches Are Still Flunking on Fourth Down
summary: There's more evidence than ever that teams be aggressive on fourth down. Why are they ignoring it?. And kicking a field goal instead of letting their star rookie quarterback Kyler Murray try to score a touchdown may have cost the Cardinals the game: They lost by six points.

title: Solomon Islands Ends Ties With Taiwan, Stands by China

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Amid Brexit, a Different Common Currency Is Raising a Ruckus
summary: Despite 300 years of union, pounds from Scottish banks-with icons such as Robert the Bruce and Robert Burns-aren't legal tender in England; 'It does my head in, the number of times people hold up my money and inspect it'. LONDON-David Swanson sheepishly shoved the bill back in his wallet. His crime? Trying to pay for two pints in a British pub with Scottish money.

title: Rock Star Ric Ocasek Is Dead
summary: He was the frontman for The Cars. NEW YORK-Ric Ocasek, famed frontman for The Cars rock band, has been found dead in a Manhattan apartment.

title: My Tale as a Cancer Survivor
summary: The 27 years after treatment have demanded endurance and vigilance. But they've also brought unexpected rewards.. Every year at about this time, I head west to Seattle. Surrounded by mountains and water, with the backdrop of the majestic Mount Rainier, the city is ideal for a pleasure trip in late summer or early fall. But I'm there for another reason: my annual checkup at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center.

title: For Cancer Survivors, What Comes Next?
summary: Resume Subscription. As more patients are successfully treated for cancer, a daunting new challenge awaits: navigating the physical and emotional challenges of being a survivor.

title: How to Make Health-Care Crowdfunding Work for Everyone
summary: Crowdfunding campaigns depend on having wealthy connections. But there are ways to make it more equitable.. Crowdfunding campaigns have become the go-to funding option for more and more people who find themselves stretched by the costs of a medical crisis, whether that consists of uninsured health-care service or medical equipment, or related costs like making up for missed earnings. But not everyone is equally able to access this source of funding: The ability to raise money online depends heavily on how wealthy a person's friends and other connections are.

title: The New, Smarter Hearing Aid
summary: The new devices are part medical device, part consumer electronics. And they may be more socially acceptable as well.. Medical devices and consumer electronics are converging to create a new generation of hearing aids.

title: New Drugs Aim to Cure Hearing Loss
summary: Researchers are trying to counter the biological causes of hearing loss-rather than just treating the effects. Scientists are pursuing the first medicines to treat hearing loss.

title: Skin Protection May Offer Surprising Benefits for Overall Health
summary: A growing body of research suggests reducing skin inflammation could help guard against chronic disease and age-related illness. A growing body of research suggests that skin may play a bigger role in fueling chronic disease and age-related illness than previously understood

title: Israel Prepares to Unleash AI on Health Care
summary: In a small country with digitized records, big data could make medicine cheaper and more effective. Israel is becoming a testing ground for the power of artificial intelligence to improve health care.

title: How Much Do You Know About Health-Care Costs? Take This Quiz
summary: What percentage of Americans put off needed care because of cost? And more in this WSJ quiz.. Almost any way you slice it, Americans spend more on health care than people in any other wealthy country. That's true if you look at total spending, about $3.5 trillion in the U.S. in 2017. It's true as a percentage of national income, at nearly 18% for the U.S. And it's true on a per capita basis, given that the U.S. spent $10,739 for every man, woman and child in the country in 2017. That's all according to the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services.

title: Boeing's Board to Weigh Engineering, Safety Changes After MAX Crashes
summary: Reorganization marks one of first tangible changes since accidents. Boeing Co. 's board is expected to consider revamping the aerospace giant's engineering department as among the first tangible internal changes following two deadly crashes of its 737 MAX airliner, a person familiar with the matter said.

title: Trump Has Few Options in Responding to Attack on Saudi Oil
summary: President faces questions about Iran strategy with depleted national-security team. WASHINGTON-The attacks on Saudi Arabia's energy-production system thrust President Trump into a fierce foreign-policy crosswind, at a time when his national security team is at its thinnest point in over a year.

title: Global Cloud Xchange Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy
summary: Reliance Communications subsidiary files for bankruptcy after reaching deal on a debt-for-equity swap with bondholders. Global Cloud Xchange filed for bankruptcy protection Sunday after reaching a deal with lenders that will erase $150 million in debt and hands control of the telecommunications company to its senior bondholders.

title: Saudi Arabia Aims to Restore a Third of Lost Oil Output Monday
summary: Strikes on Saturday knocked out 5.7 million barrels of daily production; Aramco CEO says work is underway to restore output. The loss of nearly 6% of global oil output in weekend strikes in Saudi Arabia sent crude prices soaring as officials said the kingdom was racing to restore roughly one-third of the disrupted production by day's end Monday.
